case_name: Commissioner of Income tax Mysore v. R. Hanumanthappa Son

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 704 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil appeal No. 704 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated January 4, 1967 of Mysore High Court in I.T.R.C. No. 43 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 4, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in I.T.R.C. No. 43 of 1965.

facts.text: Family of R. Hanumanthappa and son assessed as Hindu undivided family with R. Hanumanthappa as karta until partition.

anchor.surface_text: The family of R. Hanu- manthappa and son was being assessed in the status of Hindu undivided family with late R. Hanumanthappa as its karta till there was a partition

facts.text: Partition of joint family took place on November 2, 1948, dividing all family assets including cotton business.

anchor.surface_text: and all the family assets including the companyton business were divided after the disruption of the joint family which took place on November 2, 1948.

facts.text: Division among R. Hanumanthappa (Karta), R. Rama Setty (son), and R.R. Sreenivasa Murthy (grandson).

anchor.surface_text: The division took place among the following three companyarceners,  1  R. Hanumanthappa, Karta,  2  R. Rama Setty his son and  3  R.R. Sreenivasa Murthy his grandson.

facts.text: Partnership firm formed on November 22, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: After the disruption of the family the partnership firm was formed on November 22, 1948,

facts.text: Partners: R. Hanumanthappa, R. Rama Setty, R.R. Sreenivasa Murthy, and R. Gopamma (widowed daughter of R. Hanumanthappa).

anchor.surface_text: the partners being the aforesaid erstwhile three companyarceners of the Hindu Undivided family, hereinafter referred to as H. U. F. and R. Gopamma a widowed daughter of R. Hanumanthappa.

facts.text: Partnership name: R. Hanumanthappa Son, Cotton Merchants.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership worked under the name and style of R. Hanumanthappa Son, Cotton Merchants.

facts.text: Partnership did the same business as the HUF.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that it did the same business which was- being done by the H. U. F.

facts.text: Business assets and liabilities transferred to partnership as capital contribution, except few trade debts.

anchor.surface_text: The business assets and liabilities falling to each companyarceners share were entered in their personal accounts and then retransferred to the partnership firm as companytribution of capital with the exception of a few trade debts.

facts.text: Partnership deed states partners continue family business after partition.

anchor.surface_text: In the deed of partnership it was stated in paras 2 and 3 follows- WHEREAS the aforesaid R. Hanumanthappa, Rama Setty and R. R. Srinivasamurthy were carrying on, as members of a Hindu undivided family, a family business as companyton merchants, till they became divided on 2-11-1948

facts.text: Partnership deed: Sreemathi Gopamma admitted to partnership for carrying on family business after partition.

anchor.surface_text: and the said three parties desire to companytinue the family business companystituting themselves into a partnership. WHEREAS it is agreed that the aforesaid Sreemathi Gopamma shall also be admitted into the partnership

facts.text: Partnership carries on as successor to HUF business of cotton merchants, ginners and pressers.

anchor.surface_text: That the partnership shalt carry on, as successor to the business, originally carried on by the Hindu Undivided Family of Cotton Merchants Ginners and Pressers.

facts.text: Assessment for 1949-50 completed on December 29, 1949 on HUF.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment for the assessment year 1949-50 was companypleted on December 29, 1949 on the H. U. F.

facts.text: Previous year for assessment 1949-50: Deepavali year, November 30, 1947 to November 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The previous year was the Deepavali year ie. November 30, 1947 to November 1, 1948

facts.text: Assessment reopened under s.34 Mysore Act, additional demand of Rs. 2,25,942/- by ITO order dated September 23, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: This-assessment was sought to be reopened under the provisions of s. 34 of the Mysore Act and an additional demand of Rs. 2,25,942/- was raised by the order of the Income tax Officer dated September 23, 1959.

facts.text: Exemption claimed under s.25(3) Mysore Act before ITO.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Income tax Officer an exemption had been claimed on behalf of the disrupted H. U. F. under s. 25  3  of the Mysore Act.

facts.text: ITO rejected exemption claim, relied on partnership deed showing continuation.

anchor.surface_text: The Income tax Officer rejected these companytentions. Apart from other matters he relied on the clause in the partnership deed which showed that the business which was being carried on by the H. U. F. companytinued to be carried on by the partnership firm

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO's view, treated as succession not discontinuance.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the, Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the view of the Income tax officer. ... He took the view that the case was one of succession and number of discontinuance an affirmed the order of the Income tax Officer.

facts.text: Commissioner agreed with AAC.

anchor.surface_text: The Con-, missioner agreed with the reasons of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Reference under s.66(2) Mysore Act to High Court: Whether assessee entitled to exemption under s.25(3).

anchor.surface_text: On application being made under S. 66  2  of the Mysore Act the following question was ,referred for the opinion of the High Court - Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee is entitled to exemption under Section 25  3  of the Mysore Income-tax Act?

facts.text: Mysore High Court answered in favor of assessee against Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in favour of the assessee and against the Revenue.

facts.text: Facts not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are number in dispute.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no discontinuance of business, merely change of ownership from HUF to partnership.

anchor.surface_text: Thus there was numberfactual cessation of business or its discontinuance. All that happened was that previously the owner of the business was the H.U.F. and subsequently the partnership became the owner. There was merely a change of ownership and the business as such companytinued.

facts.text: Supreme Court discharges High Court answer, answers in favor of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the High Court cannot thus be sustained. The answer given by it in favour of the assessee will have to be discharged and in its place the question referred is answered in favour of the Revenue.

Before the Income tax Officer an exemption had been claimed on behalf of the disrupted H. U. F. under s. 25  3  of the Mysore Act. This provision which was in the same terms as s. 25  3  of the Indian Income tax Act, hereinafter called the Indian Act, as it stood before the amendment of 1939 was as follows - Where any business, profession or vocation on which tax was at any time charged under the, provisions of the Mysore Income tax Act 1920, is discontinued, notax shall be payable in respect of the income, profits and gains of the period between the end date of the previous year and the, date of such discontinuance, and the assessee may further claim that the income, profits and gains of the previous year shall be deemed to have been the income profits and gains of the said period.

concepts.interpretation: Requires real and factual discontinuance or complete cessation of the business itself, not merely a change of ownership from HUF to partnership firm which continues the same business as successor.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: erional or jural and in the latter case, it is real or factual. All the above decisions proceed on the footing that the requirement of sub-s.  3  of s

concepts.unlisted_description: Relief from taxation on income between end of previous year and date of discontinuance of business, profession or vocation.

anchor.surface_text: Where any business, profession or vocation on which tax was at any time charged under the, provisions of the Mysore Income tax Act 1920, is discontinued, notax shall be payable in respect of the income, profits and gains of the period between the end date of the previous year and the, date of such discontinuance... There are numerous decisions relating to the question as to what is meant by business being discontinued as also of there having been a succession with reference to s. 25  3 , of the Indian Act.

concepts.interpretation: Interpreted as complete cessation or factual discontinuance of the business activity, not notional/jural change due to partition or ownership change; uniform judicial view pre-1939 that mere succession or continuation under new ownership does not constitute discontinuance.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: 3  gave relief in the event of. discontinuance. The amendment only introduced a quali- fication that if there was a succession in respect of which.

concepts.unlisted_description: Statutory concept under income-tax law requiring factual cessation of business for tax relief, distinguished from succession or change of ownership.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave and is directed against the judgment of the Mysore High Court rendered in its advisory jurisdiction on a case stated by the Commissioner of Income tax Mysore under S. 66  2  of the Mysore Income tax Act, 1923, hereinafter called the Mysore Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for reference of questions of law to High Court by Income-tax authorities.

anchor.surface_text: This-assessment was sought to be reopened under the provisions of s. 34 of the Mysore Act and an additional demand of Rs. 2,25,942/- was raised by the order of the Income tax Officer dated September 23, 1959.

concepts.interpretation: Wide language allows special leave to appeal against any judgment of High Court, including under pre-Constitution state acts post-integration via Finance Act 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This provision which was in the same terms as s. 25  3  of the Indian Income tax Act, hereinafter called the Indian Act, as it stood before the amendment of 1939... The language of s. 25  3  of the Mysore Act was different and was the same as of the Indian Act before its amendment in 1939.

concepts.interpretation: Pre-1939 version identical to Mysore s.25(3); 1939 amendment added no relief on succession but did not alter meaning of 'discontinuance' as complete cessation.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: were numberlonger possible unless there was a reunion or partnership. It is apparent that the facts of this case were different and clearly distingui

concepts.unlisted_description: Tax relief on discontinuance of business, interpreted consistently with Mysore provision.

anchor.surface_text: By S. 3 of the Finance Act 1950, the Indian Act was amended. The following amendment is relevant for our purposes S. 3 Amendment of Act XI of 1922-With effect from 1st day of April, 1950, the following amendments shall be made in the Income tax Act,-  a  for sub-section  2  of section 1 of the following sub-section shall be substituted, namely - It extends to the whole of India, except the State of Jammu Kashmir

concepts.interpretation: Extended Indian IT Act to whole of India including erstwhile Mysore State, repealing Mysore Act via s.13; enabled appeal to SC under Art.136 against Mysore HC judgments post-1950.
concepts.unlisted_description: Amendment extending Income-tax Act, 1922 to whole of India.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee is entitled to exemption under Section 25(3) of the Mysore Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee is entitled to exemption under Section 25  3  of the Mysore Income-tax Act?

issues.text: what is meant by business being discontinued as also of there having been a succession with reference to s. 25(3) of the Indian Act

anchor.surface_text: There are numerous decisions relating to the question as to what is meant by business being discontinued as also of there having been a succession with reference to s. 25  3 , of the Indian Act.

issues.text: We have to ascertain the correct scope and ambit of the words business is discontinued which would mean discontinuance of business for the purpose of s. 25(3) of the Mysore Act

anchor.surface_text: We have to ascertain the cor rect scope and ambit of the words business is disconti- nued which Would mean discontinuance of business for the purpose of s. 25  3  of the Mysore Act

issues.text: whether the matter related to the pre-Constitution period under the Mysore Act by which the Mysore High Court had been constituted as the highest court and no appeal lay to any higher court

arguments.claim: Assessee entitled to exemption under s.25(3) as partition caused disintegration of business into parts allotted to coparceners, connoting discontinuance

anchor.surface_text: In support of the contention that there had been dis- companytinuance of the assessees business as contemplated by S. 25  3  of the Mysore Act it was urged, inter alia, before the Income tax authorities that on partition the business, had disintegrated into several parts which had been allotted individually to each companyarcener thereby connoting discontinuance of the business.

arguments.court_reasoning: No factual cessation or discontinuance; merely change of ownership from HUF to partnership which continued the business

arguments.claim: Disruption of HUF broke integrity of business, causing total cessation; analogous to Annamalai Chettiar

anchor.surface_text: A great deal of emphasis has been laid on behalf of the respondent assessee on the integrity of the business carried on by the H.U.F. having been broken by the disruption of the family and it is claimed that the business of the family must be deemed to have totally ceased or discontinued on such disruption. Reliance has been placed on a number of decisions out of which mention may be made only of N.A.S.A. Annamalai Chettiar

court_response_anchor.surface_text: separating partners are companycerned but there may be numberdiscontinuance of the business as such. Thus the word discontinuity is capable of double

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts distinguishable; here partnership deed shows explicit succession and continuation unlike split without continuation

arguments.claim: 'Discontinued' means complete cessation of business, not mere change of ownership; follows precedents like Polsons, Sanjana, Kalumal

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income tax Bombay v. P.E. Polsonl it was observed as follows- Before the amending Act came into force the words discontinued and discontinuance in Section 25 of the 1922 Act had been the subject of numerous decisions... it had been uniformly decided that these words did number cover mere change of ownership but referred only to a complete cessation of the business.

arguments.claim: 1939 amendment did not alter meaning of 'discontinuance'; only added no relief on succession

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that under the Indian Act before it was amended in 1939, s. 25 3 gave relief in the event of. discontinuance. The amendment only introduced a qualification that if there was a succession in respect of which. 1 relief was given there should number be any relief upon discontinuance. It did number enlarge or Alter the meaning of discontinuance.

arguments.claim: Discontinuance must be real/factual of the business, not notional/jural change of owners; per Bachraj Nathani

anchor.surface_text: Grille C.J., and Niyogi J., discussed elaborately the case law... This is what was said - It must be observed that sub-section 3 is ,concerned with business... the discontinuity is notional or jural and in the latter case, it is real or factual. All the above decisions proceed on the footing that the requirement of sub-s. 3 of s. 25 is that the business should be discontinued

arguments.claim: No appeal lies to Supreme Court as matter under pre-Constitution Mysore Act where High Court was final court
arguments.court_reasoning: Finance Act 1950 repealed Mysore Act and extended Indian Act; Art.136 wide enough for special leave against any HC judgment

arguments.claim: Partnership explicitly successor per deed clause 1 of clause 3; thus no discontinuance

anchor.surface_text: Here apart from the circumstances and facts which have been found and established the partnership deed made it clear that the three coparceners who had formed partnership desired to continue the family business as partners after the partition of the family. Nothing could be clearer than the language used in sub-clause 1 of clause 3 of the Partnership deed that the partnership shall carry on as successor to the business originally carried on by the H.U.F.

holdings.text: there was no factual cessation of business or its discontinuance. All that happened was that previously the owner of the business was the H.U.F. and subsequently the partnership became the owner. There was merely a change of ownership and the business as such continued.

anchor.surface_text: Thus there was nofactual cessation of business or its discontinuance. All that happened was that previously the owner of the business was the H.U.F. and subsequently the partnership became the owner. There was merely a change of ownership and the business as such continued.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partition of HUF followed by formation of partnership with coparceners and daughter explicitly as successor continuing identical business without interruption; assets transferred as capital.

holdings.text: the business was never discontinued so as to attract the provision of S. 25(3) of the Mysore Act.

anchor.surface_text: In other words the business was never discontinued so as to attract the provision of S. 25 3 of the Mysore Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No cessation of business activity; only ownership changed from HUF to partnership which carried on same business as successor per deed clause 3(1).

holdings.text: The judgment of the High Court cannot thus be sustained. The answer given by it in favour of the assessee will have to be discharged and in its place the question referred is answered in favour of the Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the High Court cannot thus be sustained. The answer given by it in favour of the assessee will have to be discharged and in its place the question referred is answered in favour of the Revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in finding discontinuance; facts show succession and continuation, not cessation qualifying for exemption under s.25(3).

holdings.text: the words discontinued and discontinuance ... did not cover mere change of ownership but referred only to a complete cessation of the business.

anchor.surface_text: it had been uniformly decided that these words did number cover mere change of ownership but referred only to a complete cessation of the business. Their lordships entertained no doubt of the correctness of these decisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniform pre-1939 judicial interpretation under Indian Act s.25(3) confirmed; 1939 amendment did not alter meaning of discontinuance, only added succession bar.

holdings.text: the discontinuity is notional or jural and in the latter case, it is real or factual. All the above decisions proceed on the footing that the requirement of sub-s. 3 of s. 25 is that the business should be discontinued

anchor.surface_text: Grille C.J., and Niyogi J., discussed elaborately the case law... This is what was said - It must be observed that sub-section 3 is concerned with business... the discontinuity is notional or jural and in the latter case, it is real or factual.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25(3) requires factual/real discontinuance of business itself, not jural change in ownership or persons; per Bachraj Nathani and consistent case law.

holdings.text: the facts of this case were different and clearly distinguishable from those of the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unlike Annamalai Chettiar where partition split business without continuation, here coparceners formed partnership as successor per explicit deed language.

holdings.text: We find no force in this objection.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Finance Act 1950 repealed Mysore Act and extended Indian IT Act to whole India; Art.136 Constitution permits special leave against any High Court judgment.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. P.E. Polson
precedents.cited_proposition: Words 'discontinued' and 'discontinuance' in Section 25(3) of 1922 Act refer to complete cessation of business, not mere change of ownership
precedents.cited_holding: Their lordships entertain no doubt of the correctness of these decisions, which appear to be in accord with the plain meaning of the section

precedents.cited_proposition: Discontinued does not cover mere change of ownership but only complete cessation of business

precedents.cited_proposition: Discontinuity under s.25(3) must be real and factual of the business itself, not notional or jural change in ownership due to death, transfer or partition
